Award.AbstractNarration: Dr. Dutton will travel to Juneau, Alaska for five days. The purpose of the trip is to meet with potential collaborators and fellowship sponsors, view laboratory facilities and meet with the research group, and discuss ideas for a fellowship proposal for the Polar Programs Postdoctoral Fellowships deadline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This postdoctoral travel fellowship in support of research was applied toward transportation costs between Santa Barbara, CA and Juneau, AK in September 2011. This travel was conducted to identify and strengthen research collaborations in support of Dr. Dutton's Postdoctoral Research Fellowship proposal to the Office of Polar Programs later that fall. During her visit, she met with Dr. Ginny Eckert at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks and also with staff at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)'s Fisheries Science Center in Auke Bay, AK. As a result of this funding, Dr. Dutton developed a research proposal to work with both Dr. Eckert and staff at the Auke Bay laboratory to study ocean acidification in polar and subpolar marine pteropods, an important ecological and fisheries-related species in Alaskan waters.

Pteropods serve as a critical food source for many commercially important species including juvenile salmon. As such, changes to pteropod populations as a result of climate changes could have significant repercussions for marine food webs in the region. Based on the meetings conducted with this funding, a proposal was submitted to the Office of Polar Programs to study ocean acidification in subpolar pteropods. The proposal was submitted in October 2010, and rejected in the summer of 2011. No further fund expenditures or project outcomes are associated with this award.


Last Modified: 09/12/2011
Modified by: Jessica M Dutton
